div.head: Schuyler Colfax and Reconstruction Policy
div.p: By the close of the Civil War, Schuyler Colfax of South Bend , Indiana, had become one of the most popular leaders in the Republican party. Elected to the national House of Representatives on the tidal wave of anti-Nebraskaism in 1854, he rose rapidly to a place of party leadership.1 His position as speaker of the house during the troubled years of 1863 to 1869 and his selection as the running mate of Ulysses S. Grant in 1868 are evidence of this fact. But the part which Colfax played in shaping reconstruction policy in the years following the Civil War has usually been underemphasized by historians. Indeed, there has been a tendency to forget the part which Colfax played, for good or ill, in the whole Civil 'War period partly because of his involvement in the Credit Mobilier scandal. Then, too, the driving, vindictive Thaddeus Stevens is usually the one held most responsible for the development of radical reconstruction policy, at least so far as the House of Representatives is concerned. But without the aid of Speaker Colfax and others, Stevens' activity would have been of no avail. Colfax was not merely a follower of Stevens in this regard, as some aver,2 but was himself responsible to a considerable extent for radical reconstruction. Although he was speaker of the House and therefore was not expected to take an active part in congressional debate, he played an important part in the formation of reconstruction policy.

div.p: Colfax belonged, of course, to the group known as radical Republicans, though lie was perhaps not quite as extreme as a few members of the group. Like other Radicals he thought at the time of the assassination of Abraham Lincoln that Andrew- Johnson was "cast in a sterner mold" than was his predecessor and that he would make treason odious.3 He was convinced, too, that "the chiefs of this gigantic rebellion of our times" were responsible for the assassination of President Lincoln .4

As the summer and fall of 1865 passed, the new President carried forward the political reconstruction of southern states under a plan very similar to Lincoln 's. Colfax, on a trip by stage coach to the west coast during this time, had little to say by way of criticism of the President's policy until on the eve of the meeting of the Thirty-ninth Congress in December. As a matter of fact, his own earlier position might well have given him pause before deciding to support any program of radical reconstruction. His view was that no act of secession could annihilate the existence of a state; on the contrary he insisted that the sovereignty of such a state still remained with the loyal people. "If the other theory is true," he added, "that a paper act of Secession is a suicide of a State, then the heroic Andrew Johnson has been sitting in the U. S. Senate illegally all winter as a Senator from Tennessee ; which I do not believe."5 By 1865, however, he seems to have forgotten entirely these sentiments.

In October, 1865, Colfax wrote a friend that, while it would be pleasant for southern congressmen to take their seats on the first day of the new session of Congress, he wanted to be
very certain that a majority of their voters are…not merely whipped back into the Union…but heartily devoted to the Union & ready to fight with us agst. all its enemies at home or abroad, now & in the future.6

As the time approached for the meeting of the new Congress to which southern congressmen would seek admission,

it became evident that this Congress would be one of the most important in our history. A careful student of reconstruction has said that the Thirty-ninth Congress, which met December 4, 1865. stood next to the First in importance.7

On November 18, a few days after arriving in Washington , Colfax, in response to a serenade, made an important speech on reconstruction policy. It was evidently a pre-arranged affair. He noted that men from the South who, at the adjournment of Congress the past March, were "struggling to blast this nation from the map of the world" proposed to enter Congress in December to "resume their former business of governing the country they struggled so earnestly to ruin." He observed that the constitution gave to each house the exclusive right to judge the qualifications of the election returns of its members, "and I apprehend they will exercise that right." He then went on to state that President Johnson, in the absence of any law passed by Congress, had prescribed certain requirements which must be met by southern states wishing to be restored to their former relations in the Union. Colfax considered these regulations "eminently wise and patriotic." He felt, however, that additional terms should be imposed on the southern states.

Stating that the Declaration of Independence must be recognized as the law of the land, he added that Negroes as well as whites must be protected in their rights of person and property and must have the right to testify and sue in the courts of the land. Another condition which the speaker would impose was that of having the new state constitutions ratified by the people. A clear majority of the people in each state, he added, must give evidence of their earnest and cheerful loyalty. He would require also that congressmen be elected who could take the oath which stated that they did not voluntarily take part in the rebellion. He thought there was danger of too precipitate action. "Let us rather make haste slowly," he said, "and we can then hope that the foundations of our Government when thus reconstructed on the basis of indisputable loyalty, will be as eternal as the stars." He concluded his speech with an avowal of faith in the President and optimistically expressed the belief that the executive

and legislative departments, "when they compare views together," would cordially cooperate.8

This speech of Colfax, who was slated for re-election as speaker, was praised by the Radicals and given close attention by all parties. This was one of the first serious jolts given to presidential reconstruction. Although the speaker said he could not anticipate the action of Congress, it was obvious that he was doing that very thing. The Washington correspondent of the Indianapolis
Journal reported that the speech had "made quite a sensation, being regarded in a measure as the key-note of action of the Republicans of Congress." He said the speech indicated that southern congressmen would not be admitted on the floor of Congress at the time of organization, that mature deliberation would characterize reconstruction, that the organization of the Republican party would not be abandoned and that the question of negro suffrage "will not be made primary, but will [be brought forward] in due time."9

The Chicago
Tribune thought the address "intentionally and frankly laid down the platform on which the House of Representatives will be called on to vote for or against him for Speaker." It thought that he might have made a more emphatic demand for negro suffrage.10 The Pennsylvania Union State Committee unanimously adopted resolutions which approved the sentiments expressed in Colfax's speech. When the resolutions were presented to Colfax, he replied that the soldiers had done their part and that it was then up to Congress to do its part.11 A Philadelphian thanked the speaker for his speech and hoped it would have an influence upon the President and the country. Lacking confidence in the executive, he said he was looking to Congress to delay reconstruction until Southerners showed themselves penitent.12 In reply to a congratulatory letter from. Charles Sumner, Colfax wrote:

In overstatement, Lew Wallace characterized the speech as
the greatest act of Mr. Colfax's life, not on account of its length or eloquence or rhetoric, but because of its consequences. It was at once accepted by the Republicans in Congress as their programme of reconstruction….If Abraham Lincoln earned immortality as the great Emancipationist, Schuyler Colfax should share the glory, for it was he who first moved to protect and assure the freeman in his freedom. Only Lincoln 's act could have been greater than Colfax's.15

These examples from Republican sources are sufficient to show the influential character of this address by Colfax. He was given considerable credit (or blame) for changing the course of reconstruction. The Chicago
Times stated editorially that before Congress met the Republicans "conspired to defeat the work of restoration begun and happily carried forward by the president, and Schuyler Colfax was a leading conspirator among them for that purpose."16 The President and his friends were likewise anything but enthusiastic about this "key-note" address. The Washington correspondent of the New York
Times said all statements to the effect that the President had expressed dissatisfaction with Colfax's speech were without foundation.17 If Secretary Gideon Welles recorded correctly, however, Johnson spoke to several cabinet members with sharpness about Colfax:

Welles said Colfax's coming to Washington was "heralded with a flourish" and that his speech was "the offspring of an intrigue, and one that is pretty extensive. The whole proceeding was premeditated."19

It was generally conceded on all sides that Colfax would be re-elected speaker of the new Congress. A typical comment was one made by the Chicago
Tribune, which said no member of the House better combined the qualifications of
experience, skill and tact as a presiding officer, devotion to Liberty, Union and true Republicanism, a knowledge of the personnel and capacities of the House, familiarity with and clear conceptions of the questions involved, and firmness in sustaining the rights of Congress [than Colfax].20
The New York
Times, desiring to see no split in the Republican forces, saw no reason to doubt the re-election of Colfax, and optimistically thought that Johnson's reconstruction policy would be adopted by Congress as the basis of its action.21

The scene on the opening day of the Thirty-ninth Congress was an interesting, not to say anxious, one. It was known that Southerners would be on hand to demand their seats and that some members of Congress would plead their cause. Long before noon the galleries and corridors were filled with anxious throngs. At the appointed time the clerk of the house, Edward McPherson, called the roll for the election of the speaker but refused to read the names of the representatives of the seceded states. Despite the furious protests of some members, the Republican majority ignored the claims of the southern gentlemen to their seats and proceeded with legislative business. Colfax was re-elected speaker by a vote of 139 to 36 over James Brooks of New York . The announcement of the vote was received with applause.22

div.p:
After being escorted to the speaker's chair by Representatives Brooks and Justin S. Morrill, the speaker reminded the House of the serious legislative tasks before it. He continued:
It is yours to mature and enact legislation which, with the concurrence of the Executive, shall establish them [the seceded states] anew on such a basis of enduring justice as will guaranty all necessary safeguards to the people, and afford, what our Magna Charta, the Declaration of Independence, proclaims is the chief object of government—protection to all men in their inalienable rights….It is for you, Representatives, to do your work as faithfully and as well as did the fearless saviors of the Union on their more dangerous arena of duty. Then we may hope to see these vacant and once abandoned seats around us gradually filling up, until this hall shall contain Representatives from every State and district….23
Little wonder that congressmen-elect from the seceded states, after hearing this opening address by the speaker, sorrowfully turned their faces homeward!

Perhaps in no way did the speaker wield greater influence in the shaping of congressional policies in those days than in the appointment of committees. At that time, it should be recalled, the speaker had the sole power of appointment. While strong pressure was exerted upon Colfax to get members upon various committees and while he no doubt listened to advice, it seems that he kept his own counsel in the matter. According to one source close to Colfax, "not five men in the House knew who a single chairman was to be."24 These committees were Radical in composition and great care was exercised in their appointment. Colfax himself later spoke of "the Radical committees I appointed invariably."25 In the appointment of the important special committee on reconstruction, the speaker took care "that a heavy majority of this committee should consist of men about whose political ‘backbone’ there is no question."26

div.p: For the next few months after the opening of Congress, it seems that Colfax tried to prevent an open break with President Johnson. Possibly he was influenced somewhat by the sentiments of his friend, Horace Greeley, who, radical though he was, asked the speaker "to take care that we do nothing calculated to drive the President into the arms of our adversaries. Let us respect his convictions and thus impel him to respect ours."27

In the meantime, the President had delivered to Congress his first message which was able, moderate, and conciliatory. He even pointed out that each house was judge of the elections, returns, and qualifications of its members.28 While the President had the aid of George Bancroft in the framing of this message, he would not have been himself had he accepted any sentiment in the message in which he did not believe. Furthermore, he had earlier indicated his belief that a limited extension of the franchise to the more able Negroes would be desirable.29 During the ensuing holiday recess of Congress, Colfax addressed the New York legislature and asked for continued confidence in the President. "Hints of distrust always beget alienation," he said. A few days later in an address at Poughkeepsie, New York , he was optimistic enough to say that "no rupture would occur between Congress and the President, and the Union will be constructed in such a manner as will be mutual for ages to come."30

Unfortunately, forces were also at work which made a harmonious development of a moderate and reasonable reconstruction policy difficult. No one person or group of persons is wholly to blame for this failure, though the Radicals must bear a very large share of the responsibility. Some were influenced by one motive and some by another. It is not necessary to conclude that humanitarianism was wholly absent from the group, but it must be admitted that the more sordid desire for political gain and economic advantage

28 James D. Richardson (ed.), A Compilation of the Messages and Papers of the Presidents, 1789–1897 (10 vols., Washington , 1896–1899), VI (1897), 358.
29 Johnson to Governor Sharkey (of Mississippi ), August 15, 1865, Indianapolis

was very impelling.31 In addition, stories, many of them exaggerated, of the mistreatment of the Negroes at the hands of southern whites greatly inflamed radical opinion. Finally, the lack of diplomacy and tact on the part of the President in dealing with men made harmony still more difficult to attain. Colfax himself seemed actuated by this whole complex of forces rather than by any one factor. Serious and impartial study of his life makes it difficult, if not impossible, to avoid the conclusion that a humanitarian desire to help an unfortunate people was one factor which motivated him. But it must be quickly added that he was sufficiently shrewd as a politician to know that harping on the rights of the blacks and waving the "bloody shirt" was good politics in northern Indiana. Since he came from a growing industrial community, it is easy to think that he might have desired to hold up the re-entrance of southern influence into our national councils until the financial and economic program of northern industrialists was better established. While it seems that this was to some extent a motivating influence in his life, Colfax was western as well as northern and thus no consistent pattern of evidence can be found on this point.32 Hence, whatever the forces were, the pressures produced by them made it difficult for bigger men than Colfax to keep their balance in this all-too-heated period.

By April, 1866, the break between the speaker and President had occurred. To a friend, the former wrote:
Like you, the inexcusable & inexplicable course of our President saddens me. But Congress will stand firm as the granite. It grows firmer every day, knowing that it stands for the Right. Tomorrow the House will pass the Civil Rights bill over the veto, & if the people only stand by Congress as firmly as Congress will stand by them, all will be well.33
When the House accordingly voted to override the President's

veto of the Civil Rights bill, the speaker, in order to make his position more emphatic, wanted his name called as a member of the House. The Radicals greeted with applause the announcement of his affirmative vote.34 Shortly thereafter, in response to a serenade by fellow-Hoosiers, he not only defended congressional reconstruction, but also said that the record that his party had made "will shine with brighter glory on our Country's page than any other in the annals of our history." Terming the Civil Rights Act as the American Magna Charta, he added that the people must look to Congress and to Congress alone for "legalized reconstruction." Colfax concluded as follows:
You will ask, perhaps, what is my policy of reconstruction. I will tell you in a few words. It is the policy of reconstruction laid down by Andrew Johnson with such emphasis and earnestness in his speeches made to the public between the month of June, 1864, and the month of May, 1865…. His radical speeches in Tennessee were indorsed by his election, and 1 stand by those declarations. They can be condensed into one single sentence, and that sentence is: "Loyal men shall govern a preserved Republic!"35

The tendency of Colfax to assume that Johnson had greatly shifted his position between 1864 arid 1866 was a common error of the Radicals. It is true that Johnson was by the latter date using less vindictive language about southern "rebels," but that was simply because he realized that the war was over while the Radicals apparently did not. In a letter on April 21, the speaker wrote:
Every day we feel Mr. Lincoln 's loss more and more keenly. Had he lived, in accord with his friends in Congress, as he would have been, the Dem. party as a political power, would have been extinguished. Now, it is quickened into new life again. But Congress will stand firmly, because it feels it stands for the Right.36
Although Lincoln probably would have been able to work along with Congress somewhat better than Johnson did, the above implication that he would have had no serious struggles with the legislative department over reconstruction is erroneous. Furthermore, it significantly appears from the above letter that one of Colfax's great disappointments was the fact

that the Democratic party did not become extinct with the close of the Civil War.

Meanwhile, the Joint Committee on Reconstruction had reported to Congress several proposals which at length became the Fourteenth Amendment and which the seceded states were required to ratify before they could be considered reconstructed. Upon the question of final passage of the amendment in the House, the speaker again directed that his name be called, although it was clear that his vote would not be decisive. "A glorious day…a day of days!" Colfax wrote to a friend referring to the passage of the amendment. "Our birthright…means something now for everyone, high and low, rich and poor…even for…. those whom God has destined to be born with a darker skin than you and I." Only Tennessee , thanks to Governor William G. Brownlow's vigorous and questionable methods, ratified the amendment.37

The issue of reconstruction was now put before the people in the congressional campaign of 1866. Though President Johnson hoped to have the voters endorse his moderate reconstruction policies, the Radicals, through "masterful campaign management, a clever use of claptrap, and vituperation against the ‘Copperheadism’ of all friends of the South,"38 were returned to Washington with greater strength than before. They were sanguine about the future and felt "that they, as victors, are ‘masters of the Situation’ and can with their two-thirds majority, ‘run the machine’ of gov't. themselves."39

When the returning Republican members of Congress were given a mass welcome in Washington , Speaker Colfax again took the occasion to sound a sort of key-note for the ensuing sessions of Congress. "We return, then," he said, "to these halls to carry out and enforce the decisions of the rulers of the nation—the people. No man can misunderstand their will." The election, he thought, settled beyond controversy the points that reconstruction must be in the hands

We have been earnestly struggling for reconstruction to come on an enduring and loyal foundation, but stumbling blocks have impeded our progress, and when at last a mild and magnanimous proposition is made, embodying no confiscation, no banishment, no penalty, of offended law, we are baffled by a hardening of heart against it as inexplicable as it seems immoveable. Does it not seem as if again the Creator is leading us in His way rather than our own, and as we turn for light does it not flash upon us that He again requires the nation to conquer its prejudices? that He, so far above us, who has put all human beings on an equality before Divine law, demands that we should put all on an equality before human law, so that every one in the region poisoned by the influence of slavery and the principles of treason shall be clothed with all the rights necessary for the fullest and surest protection against tyranny and wrong, and not left defenseless at the mercy of those who so long exhibited no mercy to the government they sought to destroy.40
Though the Republicans had said negro suffrage was not an issue in the congressional campaign and that the fourteenth amendment was not to be interpreted that way, the above statement of the speaker seemed to point the way toward more radical reconstruction legislation, including negro suffrage.41

The sequel proved such was the case. The new reconstruction legislation, passed over the President's veto on March 2, 1867, provided for virtual military government of the southern states until they adopted and ratified constitutions which provided among other things for negro suffrage and the disqualification of ex-Confederate leaders. This and supplementary legislation had the hearty support of Colfax and, together with the Tenure of Office Act passed at the same time, had the effect of maneuvering the President into a position of virtual helplessness. Quite properly he struck back at this unconstitutional disruption of our check-and-balance system, but to no avail.

So distrustful of the President had Congress become that it considered it advisable to provide for the convening of the Fortieth Congress immediately upon the adjournment of the Thirty-ninth at noon on March 4. The immediate convening

of a new Congress the moment the old was declared adjourned and that, by act of Congress rather than by call of the President, was unique in our political history. Particularly unique was the fact that the valedictory address of the speaker of the closing Congress and the inaugural of the speaker of the next should be given in the same hour and by the same man, for it was understood that Colfax would be elected speaker for the third time. In his inaugural address the speaker praised the work of the preceding Congress and said it was their duty "to so make history that posterity shall rise up and call us blessed." He thought it would be fortunate for the new Congress if, at its end, it could "point to a record which will shine on our historic page like that of the Congress which has just expired."42 Unfortunately, "posterity" has not been able to agree with this judgment. It has not risen up and called blessed the work of the Thirty-ninth and Fortieth Congresses.

Adjourning on March 30, Congress met several times during the summer and fall of 1867 in order to take care of any contingency growing out of the conflict between the legislative and executive departments. In demand as a public speaker on various occasions, Colfax used his oratorical powers to defend radical reconstruction. He stated before the Union League in New York City that the Congresses which passed the military reconstruction bill and supplementary legislation were guided "by the same Providence which gave our armies victory after victory."43 In the Ohio campaign of 1867 in which the question of negro suffrage for the state was an issue, Colfax was called in to aid the cause. At Lebanon he delivered an important address in which there was little that was new but which was one of the most radical pronouncements he had ever made. The "great and vital issue before the American people" was
whether this Government of ours is to be administered in the interest of loyalty, or in the interest of disloyalty; whether the States lately in rebellion, with their armed hordes defying the power of established government, seeking to blot this nation from the map of the world, shall be reconstructed upon the eternal granite of indisputable loyalty, or on the treacherous quicksands of unrepentant treason; whether these men, who for four years had their arms around the temple of liberty,

seeking to overwhelm us in ruin, shall have any part in the reconstruction of this country they sought to destroy. The mere fact that Southerners accepted the situation did not entitle them to special consideration, continued Colfax. "I reckon they had to." Lucifer, "thrown from the battlements of heaven," also accepted the situation; but he did not get back into the courts of heaven. Lewis T. Powell, who called himself Payne, the would-be assassin of William H. Seward, also accepted the situation; but he was hanged. And so, said Colfax, might any unrepentant rebel in the land accept the situation.44

As to the President, whose recent action in asking for the resignation of Secretary of War Edwin M. Stanton had added fuel to the flames, Colfax arraigned him for failing to execute the laws45 and for violating his oath. He thought the chief executive ought to have, "like all others, who are charged with offenses, the opportunity before that tribunal made by the Constitution, to vindicate himself from these grave charges of the people against him." Colfax continued, "I can say of our President, in the language of holy writ: ‘May his days be few, and may another take his office,’46 I mean, of course his official days." He praised Stanton in high terms and promised that after Congress met the secretary would come back to the Department of War. The President, continued the speaker, "has no right to have a policy," except that contained in the laws. Colfax's remarks on these points, as well as those on negro suffrage, were all that the most intense Radical could desire. In fact, in answer to the charge of Radicalism, the speaker replied:
Well, I am a Radical from the crown of my head to the sole of my foot—radical for the right as against the wrong, radical for justice as against injustice, radical for equality and against oppressions, radical for liberty and against slavery. I am a radical for every friend of my country, and a radical enemy for every enemy of my native land.47

Not now, we say to them, not now. As for himself, Colfax said he would "stand by the obligation of the Government to the last cent, whether popular or un- popular."48

In an address in October before a large and enthusiastic crowd at Cooper Institute, New York City, Colfax covered similar ground. But with reference to rumors of armed uprisings to aid the President in reasserting his power, Colfax added:
If there is to be another rebellion after this—if the law–making power, which is the people speaking through their Senators and Representatives, is to be trampled under foot by revolutionary force, I believe in my heart there will be some example made to go down into American history as a warning, that no man hereafter shall gamble with the peace of this country and lose nothing by the stake.49

The fall elections in a number of states in 1867 went against the Republicans. It was the most serious reaction since 1862 and caused no little concern. For Colfax and others, however, the election reverses did not mean a backing down on reconstruction. His considered judgment as voiced in a letter to a friend was
that, in spite of our political reverses … we all have faith in a Victory for the Right next year, & that, whether good or evil betide, if we see certain defeat before us, we shall not recede a hair's breadth from our Policy of Reconstruction, while our term as a Congress continues, which, thank God, is as long as apostacy can rule in the Presidential Chair—up to March 4th 1869.50
To another person he wrote that
you need not fear that Congress will take any backward steps in reconstruction. We have staked our political existence on the principle, that the States lately in rebellion shall be organized on the enduring cornerstones of loyalty and justice, and shall be led back to their old
48 Indianapolis Daily Journal, September 21, 1867.
49 Hollister, Life of Schuyler Colfax, 311; Indianapolis Daily Journal, October 24, 1867.
50 Colfax to Hannah Darlington, December 7, 1867, Colfax MSS., New York Public Library.
places in our council–halls by those who dared, amid the tornado of treason that swept over the South, to stand faithfully for liberty and the Union … I would not modify the terms of reconstruction in any essential feature, one hair's breadth.51

In the meantime, Congress had reconvened at its usual time. The big question before the congressmen during this session was the impeachment and trial of the President. While there had been some talk of impeachment for nearly two years, the movement did not gain serious headway until the regular meeting of the Fortieth Congress in December, 1867. As indicated above, Colfax was already in favor of impeachment. When the Chicago Tribune published some misleading statements in regard to his position on impeachment, he wrote the editor that he was impatiently waiting for Congress to meet in order that that body might send Stanton back to the War Department and that it might furnish a proper tribunal before which the President could defend himself against grave charges. He added that while he did not believe
Mr. Johnson dared to fulfil the threats against Congress now being made by his Washington organs, apparently in his name, yet whoever did dare to destroy the Legislative department of the government, by revolutionary force, whether President, Cabinet Minister, or citizen, would be tried for his treason, and punished as a traitor, with his feet, not like traitors of the present rebellion, on the earth, but in the air.52

When the Senate voted in January, 1868, that the reasons Johnson gave for the removal of Stanton were not sufficient, the secretary secured the keys and went back to his old office in the War Department. A large delegation of House members, headed by the speaker, called on Stanton to ask him to remain at his post under all circumstances. Colfax stated that
since the passage of the tenure–of–office law Mr. Stanton had become an officer of the people, and not removable without the consent of the Senate; that he ought not to resign unless the people demanded it and that the people wanted and expected him to retain his place. The speaker then referred to him as the Thermopylae, the pass of the greatest value to congressional reconstruction and as the one on whom the safety of reconstruction rested. He was promised the backing of the great Republican party
51 Colfax to Conway, December 8, 1867, quoted in South Bend, Indiana, St. Joseph Valley Register, January 2, 1868.
52 South Bend, Indiana, St. Joseph Valley Register, October 3, 1867.
and additional laws by Congress if necessary. Finally Colfax praised Stanton as one who carried his colors openly and as one who represented more than anyone else the policy of Lincoln and the spirit of the people who crushed the rebellion and who were determined that that victory stand to give peace to the country.53 It thus appears that Colfax was one of the leaders in the plot to "use" Stanton in the cabinet.

In February, 1868, the long–threatened action against the President took place. When the House resolved that "Andrew Johnson, President of the United States, be impeached of high crimes and misdemeanors in office," the speaker asked to have his vote cast in favor of the resolution.54 The fact that the House first voted to impeach and afterward formulated their reasons typifies the sorry character of the whole disgraceful proceeding. The committee which Colfax appointed to report articles of impeachment was headed by Thaddeus Stevens. Most of the articles centered around the alleged violation of the Tenure of Office Act by the attempted removal of Stanton. Not since the assassination of Lincoln had Washington and the country as a whole been so excited as it was during these days. The wildest rumors of violence were afloat. Even the speaker seems to have been affected by them. For example, a Mr. Kennedy, the chief of the New York police, wrote to the speaker to the effect that some nitro–glycerine had disappeared from New York and that he did not know where it had gone unless to Washington. "The chivalrous and timid speaker," wrote Secretary Welles, "at once laid this tremendous missive before the House, and the consternation of the gallant band of Radicals became excessive."55 Before impeachment proceedings were started, Colfax wrote to James A. Garfield in Europe:
I should not be surprised at any measure he [the President] might resort to. And we must expect the most exciting scenes … Don't fail to be at home to take a part, if ugly scenes are to occur. I have no fear myself but many expect them. Don't quote me on these things at all abroad. 56
The speaker received offers to defend Congress by force if
53 Frank A. Flower, Edwin McMasters Stanton, the Autocrat of Rebellion, Emancipation, and Reconstruction (Akron, Ohio, 1905), 336-37.
54 Congressional Globe, 40 Cong., 2 Sess., February 24, 1868, p. 1400.
55 Welles, Diary of Gideon Welles, III, 297.
56 Colfax to Garfield, September 11, 1867, James A. Garfield MSS., Congressional Library.
necessary. On the other hand, the President received similar offers to defend the Executive Department.57

Colfax shared the confidence of the Radicals in the certainty of the President's conviction. "Impeachment will succeed. Have faith," he wrote in the spring of 1868. If it failed, he continued, a "suffering and till now forbearing people" knew that Johnson would be "for the remaining year an uncontrolled despot, worse than ever before, with civil war probably in the fall, when he would have all the Rebels vote down South & exclude the loyal colored people."58 Like other Radicals the speaker blamed "that persistent nullifier of law" for all the ills of the country and thought that with Senator Benjamin F. Wade in the presidency "we may hope for revived prosperity, just reconstruction, and national peace."59 It seems, however, that the prosperity which the Radicals were particularly interested in reviving was that which comes from office–holding. Senator Wade in the president's chair could give the initial impulse and negro votes in the South could guarantee its continuance.60

In the event of the conviction of President Johnson, Senator Wade, president pro tempore of the Senate, was to become President. This fact, according to some evidence, gave pause to some people who thought that Wade in the presidential chair would be little improvement over Johnson. It appears that some had hoped it might be possible for Colfax, next in line after Wade, in some way or other to succeed to the presi–
57 Indianapolis Daily Journal, March 4, 1868; Oberholtzer, History of the United States Since the Civil War, I, 491-92.
58 Colfax to Heaton, n.d. but apparently written in March, 1868, Colfax MSS., Northern Indiana Historical Museum, South Bend.
59 Colfax to Union League Club in New York City, April 13, 1868, published in Indianapolis Daily Journal, April 29, 1868.
60 Swisshelm[?] to Mrs. B. F. Wade, Benjamin F. Wade MSS., Congressional Library. A letter to Mrs. Wade illustrates the first phase of the hoped-for prosperity:
"It appears probable that God is about to show mercy to this afflicted land & remove Mr. Johnson. If so Mr. Wade, as his successor will not leave the depart ments in the hands of rebels & prostitutes as they have, in so large a measure, been. Will you please call his attention to my case; & let me know if he will give me a situation when the good Lord places, in his hands, the reins of Government which I pray he may continue to hold five years."
The second phase of the desired prosperity is typified by an editorial in the Indianapolis Daily Journal, March 27, 1867.
"Now is the time to educate the South into a new school of politics. If we fail to embrace the present opportunity for building up true Republicanism there, we need not be surprised if the old rebel leaders sway the new as they did the old South."
dency. It was thought that this would make conviction of Johnson still more certain in that those having an antipathy to Wade would not need to fear about their votes for conviction making the senator President.

The story was even circulated to the effect that Wade, Senator Henry Wilson of Massachusetts, and Colfax had made a bargain along these lines: Wade was to vote for conviction and then resign, thus leaving the presidency to Colfax. Wilson and Colfax, who, with Wade, were candidates for the Republican vice–presidential nomination, were then to step out of this race and leave the price to Wade. In an interview, with the Washington correspondent of the Providence Journal, however, Senator Wade declared that he had never thought of resigning as President. Thus, while not a few would probably have preferred Colfax to Wade, it is not likely that these stories of a deal were taken seriously.61 Even though the conviction of Johnson would have made Wade President, which through the patronage power would have given him an advantage in his race for the vice–presidency, Colfax seems not to have been deterred by these considerations in his hope for conviction.62

The outcome of the trial of the President was a stunning disappointment to the Radicals. Colfax shared their intense dislike, not to say hatred, for the seven courageous Republicans who, with the Democrats, voted against conviction. Balked at this point, they were determined to make the election of 1868 another referendum on reconstruction. While some still raised questions about Grant's solidity on reconstruction, for most of them he had become Radical enough to be "let … into the church."63 Colfax himself had earlier been in a receptive mood and was talked about for first place on the ticket, but long since he had seen that policy called for Grant.64 While Republicans were determined to have an
61 Syracuse, New York, Journal, May 10, 1868, quoted in New York Times, May 16, 1868; Providence, Rhode Island, Journal, May 14, 1868, quoted in New York Times, May 23, 1868.
62 Cincinnati, Ohio, Daily Gazette, May 7, 1868; Colfax to K. G. Shryock, March 26, 1868, Colfax MSS., Chicago Historical Society Library.
63 Oberholtzer, History of the United States Since the Civil War, I, 489.
64 Colfax to Theodore Tilton, January 4, 1868, Colfax MSS., New York Public Library.
unquestioned Radical run on the ticket with Grant, it seems that, since all the leading candidates met that qualification, reconstruction policy had no bearing on the vice–presidential nomination.

In addition to the factor of personal popularity, Colfax himself admitted the influence of the Methodist conference held at the same time and place65 in bringing about his nomination.66 The fact that Colfax was a temperance man probably heightened the regard of the Methodists for him.67 Colfax himself did not take an active part in the campaign until October. Since Grant was not inclined toward public speaking and Colfax was, the greater burden fell upon the latter. His usual strategy in his speeches was to rekindle the Civil War prejudices, defend congressional reconstruction, and praise both the hero of Appomattox and the record of the Republican party. His waving of the "bloody shirt" was quite pronounced. In one speech he praised the scalawags and the carpetbaggers as the "best men of the South" —those whom these
unrepentant, these murderous traitors with their shirts and their hands red with the blood of murdered Union men, dare to condemn and denounce. … If I forsake them, may God forsake me and mine forever and ever. God helping me, I intend to stand by them.68
At Detroit, again waving the "bloody shirt," Colfax asked his audience whether there was a man there who was going to vote Democratic. If so, he said, he wanted to say a few words to him:
When you go to the ballot box and drop in that ballot by which you and the other millions of our country rule this land and control its destinies, you are going side by side, if not in actual proximity, yet in the spirit, in principle and in soul with the men who on the battlefield sought to kill you for your adherence to the flag … They drew the bead upon you; they aimed at your heart because you were faithful to the allegiance which they themselves repudiated. God's providence turned aside that bullet, but if the men with whom you are going to
65 Chicago.
66 Colfax to Rev. Dr. Eddy, July 5, 1868, Hollister, Life of Schuyler Colfax, 322–23.
67 Colfax, a religious man, belonged to the Dutch Reformed Church.
68 Chicago Tribune, October 10, 1868.
vote could have led the way you would have been bleeding in your graves. Now go and vote with them if you want to.69

In another effort the nominee said the Republican party stands upon God–given principles and allies its cause "with the Eternal throne itself." He would not wonder, he added, "if in the ages of Eternity they [Negroes] may sit in higher places than their miserable defamers."70 These excerpts are sufficient to show the type of campaign which Colfax waged. The issue of finances he seems to have side–stepped, for the reason perhaps that many western Republicans were themselves enamored with the greenback "heresy."

With his election as vice–president, Colfax ceased to be an active influence in the further development of reconstruction policy. Indeed, its main outlines had long since been formed. In the occasional addresses given he continued to defend radical reconstruction; and despite occasional rumors of difference between him and his chief, he seems to have been a strong defender of the Grant administration against a growing number of attacks. Poor reward was it then in 1872 when, for various reasons,71 the Republicans failed to renominate Colfax and selected instead Henry Wilson. On March 4, 1873, he retired from public life under the Credit Mobilier cloud and never sought to vindicate himself through re–election to any office, though to his dying day he protested his innocence. Colfax remained regular in his party affiliations in 1872, as indeed he did throughout his life, despite the treatment he received at the Republican convention that year, and despite his friendship for Greeley and the support given the Liberal Republican candidate by many of his friends. As to reconstruction, it was difficult for Colfax, Radical that he was, to follow the more moderate policy of his party under President Rutherford B. Hayes. As a good friend of Hayes, however, he wrote the newly inaugurated President that "whether conciliation will concilate or not, I and glad, & so are the vast numbers, that it is to be tried…"72

div.p: A sounder scholarship since Colfax's day has shown that on many phases of reconstruction policy Colfax and the other Radicals were wrong and their political opponents were right. But in maintaining that position, Colfax was simply a representative of his section; and for good or ill, he was an important influence in moulding the position taken by his section and by Congress.

div.head: The Immediate Purpose of the Fourteenth Amendment
div.p: In recent years much emphasis has been placed on certain possible subtle purposes involved in the framing of the Fourteenth Amendment. Such writers as Charles and Mary Beard have emphasized suspected economic motives in such a vivid manner that some writers have come to ignore other and possibly more potent factors. While their interest has been largely absorbed in the possibility of framers' seeking to safeguard corporations against hostile legislation, they have tended to minimize the rather clear evidence concerning immediate political objectives. Scholars have been inclined to refrain from an analysis of what most framers and party leaders in general hoped to achieve by means of the Fourteenth Amendment.

The evidence for such a study, found in the private letters and public speeches of participants as well as in the newspaper comment of the period, leads us down an open road with easily seen milestones to the following conclusions:
1. That the basic purpose of Radicals in 1865 and 1866 was party control.
2. That they desired negro suffrage as a means to this end.
3. That when efforts to secure negro suffrage through executive action in 1865 had failed, Radicals turned to Congress and used popular agitation to bring pressure to bear on that body.
4. That it soon became evident that public opinion would not sustain such a step by Congress in 1866.
5. That Radicals then came to realize that some statement of policy must be framed which would offer to all Republicans a common meeting ground and which would present an attractive platform to voters then clamoring for a restoration plan.
6. That the Fourteenth Amendment, this political platform, was not a Radical document but one that compromised all Radical purposes in the name of temporary political expediency.
7. That its object was not to settle the issue of reconstruction, but to postpone a settlement, while maintaining party control, until such a time as public opinion would endorse what was deemed necessary for party security—negro suffrage.

With the return of peace in the spring of 1865, divisions already present within the Republican party were accentuated by the new problem of restoration. Now that the Negro's freedom from slavery was assured, the extreme faction known as Radicals began intensive agitation for his enfranchisement. This was deemed politically expedient; for representatives from restored states, selected by an unchanged electorate, could be expected to cooperate with the existing congressional minority of northern Democrats.

For a time it was thought that Abraham Lincoln's successor might help the Radicals achieve their purpose through executive power and influence. Before long, however, Andrew Johnson's North Carolina proclamation indicated that too much dependence on his support would be unwise. Delay was then urged, while strenuous efforts were made to create a public sentiment calculated to influence the Thirty–ninth Congress for negro suffrage. Wendell Phillips had already urged Charles Sumner to "begin on agitation—we will see that it reaches the Senate doors by December."1 Nevertheless, until a more propitious moment, it was thought best by many to maintain the outward appearance of party unity. Possibly the administration might yet be drawn into the Radical orbit. The cabinet itself included at least three members who favored the extremists' program.

Several congressmen who later figured prominently in the framing of the Fourteenth Amendment committed themselves definitely in favor of negro suffrage in the summer of 1865. John A. Bingham of Ohio, George S. Boutwell of Massachusetts, Thaddeus Stevens of Pennsylvania, Jacob M. Howard of Michigan, and William P. Fessenden of Maine expressed their approval during this time. All were to serve on the joint committee which shaped the amendment. Stevens and Fessenden were chairmen of the House and Senate portions respectively. The latter presided at its joint sessions. These men took their stand for black voters more on the basis of national safety through continued control of the Republican party than on broad humanitarian principles.

Howard of Michigan wished to "put it on the ground of public safety and necessity." He urged New Englanders, with their record of humanitarian arguments, to refrain
1 Wendell Phillips to Charles Sumner, March 10, 1865, Sumner Papers (Harvard University Library).
from taking too prominent a position in this suffrage struggle.2 "The negro must vote," Howard emphatically declared. "It is our only security and the only means of making emancipation effectual. He must vote."3

As early as June, Attorney–General James Speed had declared himself "unequivocally for negro suffrage."4 Another cabinet member, James Harlan, voiced his support, but declared that negro suffrage could not be expected for some time.5 Henry Winter Davis, as zealous as any for the colored vote, shared Harlan's lack of optimism. On such an issue, he was convinced that the Radicals would "certainly be beaten." Despite these fears, Davis predicted that delay would allow the old "coalition" to regain power.6 Gloomily he voiced his fear that Johnson's policies would consign "the great Union, or Republican party, bound hand and foot, to the tender mercies of the rebels." Continuation of the present system without negro suffrage seemed to him to mean simply political suicide for his party.7

In answer to those who feared improper use of the ballot by the Negro, Ben Butler expressed this practical Radical analysis: "If the master votes right, let the negro vote with him. If the master votes wrong, then we gain the chance that the negro may not vote with the master. That chance is worth something. Thus we gain and can lose nothing by giving the negro the right to vote."8

By late summer most Radicals had given up the President as useless for their purpose. Despite this reaction, they feared to break openly with Johnson and conservative Republicans, for this would accomplish what they most dreaded—the return of Democrats to power. They preferred to continue their crusade privately while apparently remaining in harmony with the administration. Men of this conviction, like Harlan of Johnson's cabinet, were prepared to accept the nearest thing to negro suffrage that could be obtained.9

3 Howard to Sumner, June 22, 1865, Sumner Papers.
4 George S. Boutwell to Sumner, June 12, 1865, Sumner Papers.

Secretary Hugh McCulloch flatly informed Sumner that if the Republicans went into an election on the suffrage issue, Democrats would win in three–fourths of the northern states.10 Stevens advised avoiding the suffrage issue completely for the time being.11

When elections in northern states where negro suffrage was an issue gave evidence of popular disapproval, most congressional leaders came to accept the more prudent course of falling back to less extreme positions till a better opportunity should offer itself.12 Consternation over these early election returns brought forth the kind of letter that James A. Garfield wrote to Salmon P. Chase: "If we shall not be able to maintain the fight on the suffrage question alone—should we not make a preliminary resistance to immediate restoration and thereby gain time?"13 Radical speakers and the Radical press qualified their previous unequivocal statements and began privately to urge the preparation of the public mind for negro suffrage by methods which they termed "education."

Frightened Radicals, subdued by the feeling that the time was not ripe for negro suffrage, showed a growing tendency to consider the use of "other topics, nearer to the popular appreciation … to unite enough to prevent final action for the present."14

Some thought it less possible to nullify Democratic votes in the South by negro ballots than to reduce the voice of the entire section in Congress. Formerly blacks had been reckoned at three–fifths of their actual number, but as freedmen they must be counted on an equal basis with others, thus swelling the representation of recently rebellious states. To many in the North this would not be tolerable. By presenting to seceded states the alternative of negro suffrage or reduced representation as a condition of restoration, the problem might be solved.

Among the several proposals to achieve this end, a plan to change the basis of representation from population to voters received wide support for a time. This was soon dis–

11 Thaddeus Stevens to Sumner, August 26, 1865, Sumner Papers.
12 New York Times, October 23, 1865.
13 James A. Garfield to Salmon P. Chase, October 4, 1865, Chase Papers (Division of Manuscripts, Library of Congress).

carded when it was discovered that such a change would not affect all sections of the North equally. Any tampering with relative representation among loyal states was recognized as political dynamite.

Other popular topics eagerly grasped by those politicians seeking substitute issues included the guaranteeing of all national obligations. These would embrace pensions and other claims as well as bonds. Although no opposition to such payment is apparent, Radicals built up a phobia that the return of southern representatives to Congress, where their coalition with northern Democrats was predicted, would lead to repudiation. One purpose of this movement is obvious upon examination of Radical statements that negro suffrage in the South would effectively counteract these dangers. Agitation for financial guarantees progressed so far that the secretary of the treasury begged its instigators to pause lest the national credit suffer.15 Sentiment for disqualification of ex–Confederates, though a natural growth, well suited Radical purposes. The movement to guarantee civil rights, sponsored originally by the more conservative Republicans, received emphasis from Radicals only when state elections indicated that suffrage would not serve as a party platform.

In fact, negro suffrage had been so completely withdrawn in favor of other more acceptable topics that Schuyler Colfax, speaking a fortnight before Congress convened in Washington, refrained from any reference to negro suffrage.16 This seems especially significant since he was soon to be elected speaker of the house, and his words were to be widely circulated as the voice of the Republican majority.

As Congress assembled, the movement to amend the Constitution precipitated a veritable avalanche of proposals centering around the negro problem. John Greenleaf Whittier's greeting "To the Thirty–ninth Congress"17 sums up the dominant purposes seen in these:
Make all men peers before the law,
Take hands from off the negro's throat,
Give black and white an equal vote.

Among those who proposed amendments on representa–
15 McCulloch to Sumner, August 16, 1865, Sumner Papers.
16 Chicago Tribune, November 20, 1865.
17 Nation (New York, 1865– ), I (1865), 714.
tion, most, like Stevens, thought and talked of the necessity of securing the "perpetual ascendency of the party of the Union." Specifically, Stevens hoped to reduce the South's representation in Congress by "about thirty–seven" or "to divide the representation and thus continue the Republican ascendency."18

Even those who were not eager for negro suffrage appreciated the value of reducing Southern representation. While Radicals wished to obtain negro suffrage as the price of southern recognition in Congress, the more moderate desired, as a matter of safety, to reduce the South's quota of representatives. It seemed, too, as the Nation pointed out, that it probably would not encounter executive opposition and would be "an entirely safe issue for this Congress…"19

Most Radicals realized the inopportuneness of an election campaign based on negro suffrage. Signs all pointed to the failure of such a move. James G. Blaine later wrote of the "ample excuse for the reluctance of leading statesmen to adopt it as a condition of reconstruction, and force it upon the South by law before it had been adopted by the moral sense of the North."20

Some Radicals liked to hear the babble of voices offering multitudes of panaceas, for that meant precious months of delay. "This discussion will go on for months," wrote Sumner, "nor do I think it desirable to stop it. At last the evidence as reported will show the necessity of interference by Congress."21

As time went on, however, leading party strategists rea ized their growing disunity and the desirability of closing ranks before the congressional elections of the summer and fall. J. W. Forney urged Sumner to cease his opposition to the President since division could only mean defeat.22 Fessenden, chairman of the Joint Committee on Reconstruction, was especially cognizant of the embarrassments to the party caused "by men of extreme opinions."23 He saw great difficul–
18 Congressional Globe, 29 Cong., 1 Sess., December 18, 1865, p. 74.
19 Nation, II (1866), 3.
20 James G. Blaine, Twenty Years of Congress (2 vols., Norwich, Conn., 1884–1886), II, 244.
21 Sumner to Carl Schurz, December 25, 1865, Schurz Papers (Division of Manuscripts, Library of Congress).
22 J. W. Forney to Sumner, December 26, 1865, Sumner Papers.
23 Francis Fessenden, Life and Public Services of William Pitt Fessenden (2 vols., Boston, 1907), II, 18.
ties in preventing a quarrel with Johnson, yet believed it necessary to avoid a party rupture at all costs.24

Colfax, speaker of the house, was just as aware of the political dangers of disunion and of taking a position in advance of the people. Scrawled beneath a group of suggestions which he turned over to the joint committee were these words: "On reflection I think the more general you make your plan when first presented the stronger it will be, avoiding carping as to details and verbage. Then if it strikes the public mind of Congress and the country favorably the details can be arranged afterwards, or modified as the exigency requires." Colfax had first thought that the amendment should be ratified by conventions. He had later crossed out that word and had substituted "legislatures." His reason for this change is not known, but his analysis of the political situation indicates a possible motive. Interestingly enough, Colfax, while wishing to avoid a popular test of the amendment in northern states, wished to provide that a majority of southern voters must approve. It is suggestive of Speaker Colfax's outlook that the suffrage question is not even mentioned in his proposals.25 Another communication of the speaker indicates that he would have liked to postpone many issues till the next Congress, when he hoped that Radicals would be stronger in both houses.26 There seems to have been a recognized danger of pressing for too much too soon.

When Stevens faced the House to urge the adoption of the joint committee's resolution on representation—which would deprive the South of votes in that body in proportion to Negroes denied the vote—he freely predicted that should the amendment fail, the whole government must fall into secessionists' hands in the next election.27

This amendment was much less than the suffrage that Stevens desired, but he was practical enough to be satisfied with what Sumner called a half–way measure. Fessenden, who defended the proposal against the attacks of the Massachusetts senator in the other house, admitted that the issue was not primarily what was most desirable, but "what can

25 Thaddeus Stevens Papers (Division of Manuscripts, Library of Congress), IV, item 53297.
26 Schuyler Colfax to "Wheeler," January 8, 1866, Colfax Papers (Division of Manuscripts, Library of Congress).
27 Congressional Globe, 39 Cong., 1 Sess., January 31, 1866, p. 537.
pass?" He explained that the greatest merit of the measure was the possibility of its adoption since it "accomplishes indirectly what we may not have the power to accomplish directly."28 Even some of Sumner's correspondents could see the practical difficulties. They wrote: "If we cannot have all we need, we must take what we can get."29

George H. Williams of Oregon, member of the joint committee, stated in debate that it was far more important to limit southern representation, for a while at least, than to provide "that negroes anywhere should immediately vote."30 So openly had the members of the committee stated their partisan purpose in presenting the amendment that Thomas A. Hendricks of Indiana built an attacking speech around quotations from them.31

Ultra–Radicals, who still hoped for direct suffrage, worked from the beginning to kill the proposed representation amendment, identical in principle with that later incorporated in the Fourteenth Amendment. A number of conservative senators drifted into the opposition also, not because they personally opposed it, but because evidence of a contrary public sentiment caused them first to hesitate, then to take a timid stand against it. The press was generally critical from the beginning. Correspondence of public men, especially from the West, contained a large volume of adverse comment. Even some of Sumner's friends advised that public opinion would not allow more drastic measures: "You will defeat the only constitutional measure that can be enacted at this time tending to the consummation of your wishes in regard to universal suffrage."32 Finally, a majority, but not two–thirds of the Senate, voted for the measure, several Republicans voting with the opposition Democrats. Fessenden lamented the loss of the representation measure, "for we can get nothing so good. If we carry any other through Congress it will not be adopted by the States…"33

The resolution to admit Tennessee was, coin-cidentally or deliberately, reported at that time by the joint committee. John A. Stewart advised the chairman of that committee that he should not allow a rupture with the executive as long as hope of compromise was possible. "You may depend upon it." he wrote, "that moderate measures alone will give you compactness and power."34
Rutherford B. Hayes of Ohio also expressed this general uncertainty and tendency toward compromise.35

After the defeat of the representation measure in the Senate, the Nation remarked editorially that Congress would have to find something on which two-thirds could rally, "or else do worse by leaving the Constitution as it is, and the Union as it was."36 When William M. Steward of Nevada , friend of the President, presented his plan for an amendment including equal suffrage, the Nation hopefully pointed out that it might offer a meeting ground for all factions.37 Clearly there were those who were seeking unity.

While political activity in the various states was increasing, and before Johnson's attitude on the Civil Rights bill was known, John Sherman claimed before a Connecticut audience that Congress and the President were in substantial accord. Republicans would not quarrel and divide just to please Democrats.38

Whatever it might signify, there was certainly much internal confusion in the Radical ranks. One Washington correspondent described the capital city as "a political chaos. No two prominent men think alike. Congress is very weak and powerless, because there is no unity of purpose or action in that body."39

It was generally understood that a difference of opinion existed in the joint committee "as to the present expediency

35
Rutherford B. Hayes to S. Birchard, March 2 and 4,. 1866, Charles R. Williams (ed.), Dzary and Letters of Rutherford Birchard Hayes (5 vols., Columbus , Ohio , 1922–1926), 111 (1924), 19.
36 Nation, 11, 323.

of a radical measure extending the elective franchise to men of all races and colors."40

Something was needed to regain lost prestige and to rally hesitating Republicans of all faiths into a solid front. Congress was being criticized for its failure to present a plan of reconstruction. All it had done, said the Nation, was to report a series of measures forming no part of any "well-defined plan, and not based upon any well-defined principle."41 "The people are clamoring more for a policy on this subject, than they could suffer from a bad one," wrote one of Stevens' correspondents. Delay in formulating such a policy seemed dangerous since the President had one already before the people. "We are in the position on this subject that a party is that has no candidate in the field."42

James H. Lane of Kansas was quoted as saying that the Republican party could now be saved only by admitting at least some states soon enough to satisfy Johnson's demands.43 Many alarmed voices testified to the need of compromise in order to hold the party together and of action in order to hold popular support.

Newspapers reflected their correspondents' observations that Radicals had begun to realize the inadequacy of talk and the necessity for action. Recognition of this criticism of delay is seen in the speech made by Colfax on the night of April 10. He announced that "Congress had only just received all of the official documents" revealing southern conditions and was at last ready to define its policy.44

At this point Robert Dale Owen appeared with his highly publicized plan of postponing negro suffrage until 1876 and reducing southern representation prior to that date. Stevens was principally impressed by the possibility of its passage. He told Owen that the required majority in Congress or among the states could not be mustered for immediate negro suffrage.45 Though Sumner did not favor the Owen plan, he also admitted that a measure for negro suffrage could not pass in 1866.46

div.p:
By April 16, the committee on reconstruction seemed to have some hope of justifying Colfax's promise of a policy.47 After a series of meetings in which some differences in regard to basic policy appeared, the New York
Times reported that the principal division had been between those determined to obtain negro suffrage and those "willing to throw the question overboard."48

Various state congressional delegations had been meeting from time to time to determine what stand on public issues would be supported by their constituents. Just before the alleged differences of opinion on the joint committee, such groups representing midwestern states were reported to have accepted the strategy of avoiding extreme policies because they might easily bring defeat.49 Stevens told Owen that some House members had informed him they would support no plan containing "a nigger in the woodpile."50 Fessenden later disclosed that the "first proposition had been voted down in committee because it was thought that Congress and the people of the Western States would not accept it."51

The influence of these meetings is further suggested by the instance of the New York delegation which met and came to certain conclusions as to what was safe as an election platform. Roscoe Conkling and Wiley P. Harris of the joint committee, which had not then agreed on any plan, were of this group. The delegation endorsed a constitutional amendment reducing representation in proportion to denial of the suffrage to any class, prohibiting payment of the rebel debt or compensation for emancipated slaves, and excluding from federal office all high officials of the Confederacy and those convicted of mistreating prisoners.52 A comparison of these points with those included in the Fourteenth Amendment seems to indicate more than coincidence.

A complete change of the amendment formerly agreed upon took place on April 28. Stevens told Owen that "we

48
New York
Times, April 26, 1866.
49 Ibid., April 26, 1866.
50 Owen, "Political Results from the Varioloid," Atlantic Monthly, XXXV, 666.
51 Fessenden, Life of Fewenden, II, 23.

contrived to patch together" the amendment in three hours,53 although the press reported that "the meeting lasted four hours."54 At the same time that the proposal for a Fourteenth Amendment was accepted by the committee, that body also altered a previous decision in regard to its importance as a condition of reconstruction. It is indeed interesting that on the same day that the committee dropped all ideas of enforced negro suffrage, it also agreed to make restoration permissible, instead of compulsory, by substituting "may" for "shall" in a proposed restoration bill. At the same time, the committee rejected a motion to make its present recommendation the sole condition of restoration.55 Apparently the dominant group had decided on a program of delay, rather than of surrender, on the issue of suffrage.

The amendment was certainly no victory for anyone, least of all the Radicals. James W. Grimes, who represented a view similar to that of Fessenden, confessed that though acceptable, it was "not exactly what any of us anted. "56 How well the committee had achieved compromise is evidenced by the results of unofficial polls and the analysis of political observers. Some disappointment is revealed; nevertheless, also evident was a general willingness to accept the proposition as reported.

Even Sumner seemed inclined to support it.57 Chief Justice Salmon P. Chase, radical as he had been on many points including negro suffrage, took a rather conservative view and gave it general approval, although he thought that "overloading the ship with amendment freight" was a mistake.58 A part of the Radical press expressed unenthusiastic support, but lamented that timid souls had exercised too much influence. Stevens himself was criticized for willingness to sacrifice principle for public support. Certain it is that the amendment was far from the real objective of Stevens in regard to reconstruction. Apparently the spectre of defeat in the approaching elections inspired unwonted timidity in the minds of many important Radicals.

div.p: Fessenden did not claim unusual virtues for the amendment but thought it the best that could be agreed upon and still be acceptable to the people. These considerations had been deemed the most important by the committee, declared its chairman.59

The Cincinnati
Commercial concluded, despite the fact that the amendment looked too much like a party platform, that it might serve better in that capacity than anything else that Congress had done.60 Fessenden's statement, "…our new platform is a very strong one," tends to confirm this analysis with an official stamp of approval.61

The Nation agreed with the Chicago
Tribune 62 in its conclusion that the amendment had so few friends and so few enemies that it might be considered "feeble." The only reason for accepting such a document would be "fear of doing worse and an unwillingness to dissolve Congress and go to the people without some tangible scheme of a restoration of the whole Union."63 Press comment very generally recognized that the discarding of Radical dogma indicated that political necessity had dictated compromise.

Years later Carl Schurz wrote, with the wisdom of hindsight, that although there had appeared to be danger to the party, perhaps it had not been as great as most had thought. According to Schurz, Radicals believed that political defeat would ruin all chances of realizing their program. Consequently, the amendment had been devised as a compromise, a "mere expedient" in order to save themselves and press toward their real goal when it seemed more attainable.64

Stevens, in opening the debate in the House, confessed that the amendment fell far short of his and the committee's wishes. "I believe it is all that can be obtained in the present state of public opinion," he added. After carefully surveying the whole situation, "we did not believe that nineteen of the loyal states could be induced to ratify any proposition more stringent than this." Because of the earlier defeat of the proposed representation amendment, he felt that the present

60

61 Fessenden, Life of Fessenden, II, 62.

measure was all that could pass Congress.65 These statements are somewhat official, for Stevens, the leader of the House representation on the committee, read them in one of the few written speeches ever delivered by that grim old Radical.

The section of the proposed Fourteenth Amendment disfranchising ex-Confederates drew most of the attacking fire. This, it was feared, would appear too partisan and would ruin all hope of ratification. How important the section in question was to Radical leadership is demonstrated by Stevens' angry words in closing the debate: Without this provision "that side of the House will be filled with yelling secessionists and hissing copperheads. Give us the third section or give us nothing," he challenged.66 Although the section passed the House, it was killed in the Senate.

As much modified as the amendment now had been in the direction of less radical measures, many constituents urged Republican senators to vote down the proposal before it brought them defeat at the polls. A member of the Central Committee of the Union Party in Ohio wrote John Sherman that, though some states would ratify, not three-fourths of the northern states would. The next presidency would be lost if this amendment were insisted upon, wrote the Ohio p~litician.67

Political leaders who predicted alteration of the amendment in the Senate knew whereof they spoke: An informal caucus agreed to strike the disfranchising section and to substitute a provision disqualifying ex-Confederate leaders from public office68—a much milder measure.

Senator Howard, who took charge of the amendment in the Senate, clearly stated that he and others of the committee had preferred negro suffrage but that it was really a question of what could be ratified. The Michigan senator declared that three-fourths of the states could not, in the opinion of the committee, be induced to ratify a suffrage proposal. He did not support the disfranchising section, and advised its deletion which the caucus was supposed to have already approved.69
